sub_topic: Solving nonlinear equations using Newton-Raphson method
message_1:
Consider the nonlinear equation: 

f(x) = x^3 - 5x + 3 = 0 

Use the Newton-Raphson method to find the root of this equation correct to 3 decimal places, starting with an initial guess x0 = 2.
message_2:
To use the Newton-Raphson method, we first need to find the derivative of the function f(x):

f'(x) = d/dx (x^3 - 5x + 3) = 3x^2 - 5

The Newton-Raphson formula is:

x_(n+1) = x_n - f(x_n) / f'(x_n)

We start with an initial guess x0 = 2. Now we will iterate the formula until we reach the desired accuracy of 3 decimal places.

Iteration 1:
x1 = x0 - f(x0) / f'(x0) = 2 - (2^3 - 5*2 + 3) / (3*(2^2) - 5) = 2 - (8 - 10 + 3) / (12 - 5) = 2 - 1 / 7 = 1.857

Iteration 2:
x2 = x1 - f(x1) / f'(x1) = 1.857 - (1.857^3 - 5*1.857 + 3) / (3*(1.857^2) - 5) ≈ 1.857 - (-0.481) / 6.485 ≈ 1.932

Iteration 3:
x3 = x2 - f(x2) / f'(x2) = 1.932 - (1.932^3 - 5*1.932 + 3) / (3*(1.932^2) - 5) ≈ 1.932 - (-0.019) / 6.998 ≈ 1.935

Iteration 4:
x4 = x3 - f(x3) / f'(x3) = 1.935 - (1.935^3 - 5*1.935 + 3) / (3*(1.935^2) - 5) ≈ 1.935 - (-0.0001) / 7.014 ≈ 1.935

At this point, the result has converged to 3 decimal places, so the root of the equation is approximately x ≈ 1.935.
